comment_text.mn120:1.1: This sutta describes a practice by which a mendicant may choose their place of rebirth. This stands in contrast with the normal approach, where a mendicant aims to be free of all rebirth. At MN 16:12.1, a mendicant who practices out of desire for rebirth is said to be bound by an “emotional shackle” (cetasovinibandha). At AN 3.18, the mendicants are said to be horrified by the suggestion that they practice for rebirth as a god, while AN 7.50:9.1 suggests that such aspirations stem from unresolved sexual desire. The present sutta takes a more conciliatory stance, moving from desire for progressively more refined kinds of rebirth to ultimately letting go of rebirth altogether.
comment_text.mn120:2.1: Here saṅkhāra has the same sense “choice” that it has in dependent origination or the five aggregates. In each case, it is the mental volition that is motivated by morally meaningful forces, either greed, hate, and delusion or their opposites, and which creates results according to that moral force. Often this works unconsciously, as the effects of our choices and deeds manifest with or without our comprehension. Here, someone who understands kamma turns it to their advantage by consciously developing an aspiration for a particular desired result. | Upapatti is one of several terms in Pali that regularly mean “rebirth”, such as jāti, (abhi)-nibbatti, okkanti, and punabbhava.
comment_text.mn120:3.1: The aspiration alone is not enough. It only works if the person already has the kammic potential to realize their aims. | In this discourse it is a mendicant who is making the aspiration. The related passages at DN 33:3.1.98 and AN 8.35 focus on “rebirth by giving”, implying the aspirant is a lay person.
comment_text.mn120:12.4: The text does not say what “pervading” (pharitvā) means, but presumably it is the “divine meditations” (brahmavihāra), which are said to be “spread” or “pervaded” (eg. MN 7:13.1). See also MN 127:8.2.
comment_text.mn120:12.12: This passage raises the question as to how such a reflection leads to rebirth in the Brahmā realms, which requires the development of absorption (eg. AN 4.123). Similar passages take care to specify that in order to be reborn in the Brahmā realm, one must not only be ethical, but “free of desire”, by which they imply the practice of absorption (DN 33:3.1.136 = AN 8.35:4.11). Related passages in Chinese translation relate the development of different levels of absorption to rebirth in the various realms (MA 168 at T i 700c7; Dharmaskandha, T 1537 at T xxvi 506b14), as does the commentary to this sutta. Now, while the current sutta does not mention absorption, it may be considered in light of the meditation practice of the six recollections. One of these is the recollection that the deities, including Brahmās, were reborn due to their faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom—exactly the same qualities mentioned in the present sutta (AN 6.25:6.3). Thus when the present sutta says to “settle on that thought, concentrate on it, and develop it”, the phrase cittaṁ bhāveti implies more than simply “developing the thought” of the aspiration, but means “developing the mind”. In the suttas this implies deep meditation, as for example the case of a teacher of the past, Sunetta, who was “free of desire”; after “developing the mind of love” (mettaṁ cittaṁ bhāvetvā) he was reborn in the Brahmā realm (AN 7.66:13.1). Thus we can interpret the present passage as a way of practicing recollection of the deities, recalling that one’s virtuous qualities are shared with the deities, and developing deep meditation based on the joy that brings.
comment_text.mn120:18.9: Legend has it that on the slopes of Mount Meru grows the vast Jambu tree that gives the continent of India her name, “the land of the black plum tree”. The fruits of that tree are as big as elephants, and when they fall, their juice flows forth as a river named Jambu. The dried mud of that river yields gold nuggets whose unparalleled lustre is highly sought-after among the gods. This is that gold (Śiva Purāṇa 17.16–19).
comment_text.mn120:37.7: Just as rebirth in the realms of higher divinity implies the corresponding level of absorption, freedom from rebirth implies the whole eightfold path.

translation_text.mn120:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn120:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn120:2.1: “I shall teach you rebirth by choice.
translation_text.mn120:2.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn120:3.1: “Take a mendicant who has faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
translation_text.mn120:3.3: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of well-to-do aristocrats!’
translation_text.mn120:3.4: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it.
translation_text.mn120:3.5: Those choices and meditations of theirs, developed and cultivated like this, lead to rebirth there.
translation_text.mn120:3.6: This is the path and the practice that leads to rebirth there.
translation_text.mn120:4-5.1: Furthermore, take a mendicant who has faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

translation_text.mn120:13-16.11: As a person with clear eyes might pick up five gallnuts in their hand and examine them,
translation_text.mn120:13-16.12: so too the Divinity of five thousand meditates focused on pervading a five-thousandfold galaxy,
translation_text.mn120:13-16.13: as well as the sentient beings reborn there.
translation_text.mn120:13-16.15: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the Divinity of five thousand!’
translation_text.mn120:13-16.16: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it.
translation_text.mn120:13-16.17: Those choices and meditations of theirs, developed and cultivated like this, lead to rebirth there.
translation_text.mn120:13-16.18: This is the path and the practice that leads to rebirth there.
translation_text.mn120:17.1: Furthermore, take a mendicant who has faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
translation_text.mn120:17.5: ‘The Divinity of ten thousand is long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’
translation_text.mn120:17.6: Now the Divinity of ten thousand meditates focused on pervading a ten-thousandfold galaxy,
translation_text.mn120:17.7: as well as the sentient beings reborn there.
translation_text.mn120:17.8: Suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally lustrous, eight-faceted, well-worked. When placed on a cream rug it would shine and glow and radiate.
translation_text.mn120:17.9: In the same way the Divinity of ten thousand meditates focused on pervading a ten-thousandfold galaxy,
translation_text.mn120:17.10: as well as the sentient beings reborn there.
translation_text.mn120:17.12: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the Divinity of ten thousand!’
translation_text.mn120:17.13: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it.
translation_text.mn120:17.14: Those choices and meditations of theirs, developed and cultivated like this, lead to rebirth there.
translation_text.mn120:17.15: This is the path and the practice that leads to rebirth there.
translation_text.mn120:18.1: Furthermore, take a mendicant who has faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
translation_text.mn120:18.6: ‘The Divinity of a hundred thousand is long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’
translation_text.mn120:18.7: Now the Divinity of a hundred thousand meditates focused on pervading a hundred-thousandfold galaxy,
translation_text.mn120:18.8: as well as the sentient beings reborn there.
translation_text.mn120:18.9: Suppose there was a pendant of Black Plum River gold, fashioned by a deft smith, well wrought in the forge. When placed on a cream rug it would shine and glow and radiate.
translation_text.mn120:18.10: In the same way the Divinity of a hundred thousand meditates focused on pervading a hundred-thousandfold galaxy,
translation_text.mn120:18.11: as well as the sentient beings reborn there.
translation_text.mn120:18.13: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the Divinity of a hundred thousand!’
translation_text.mn120:18.14: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it.
translation_text.mn120:18.15: Those choices and meditations of theirs, developed and cultivated like this, lead to rebirth there.
translation_text.mn120:18.16: This is the path and the practice that leads to rebirth there.
translation_text.mn120:19.1: Furthermore, take a mendicant who has faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
translation_text.mn120:31.6: the gods of the dimension of infinite space …
translation_text.mn120:32.6: the gods of the dimension of infinite consciousness …
translation_text.mn120:33-36.6: the gods of the dimension of nothingness …
translation_text.mn120:33-36.7: the gods of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’
translation_text.mn120:33-36.9: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception!’
translation_text.mn120:33-36.10: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it.
translation_text.mn120:33-36.11: Those choices and meditations of theirs, developed and cultivated like this, lead to rebirth there.
translation_text.mn120:33-36.12: This is the path and the practice that leads to rebirth there.
translation_text.mn120:37.1: Furthermore, take a mendicant who has faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
translation_text.mn120:37.6: ‘If only I might realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
translation_text.mn120:37.7: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn120:37.8: And, mendicants, that mendicant is not reborn anywhere.”
translation_text.mn120:37.9: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn120:37.10: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
